Borrow a Shakespeare reinterpretation by a top novelist this Shakespeare Week

Written by Brandon King · Published Mar 12, 2018

For more than four hundred years, Shakespeare‚Äôs works have been performed, read, and loved throughout the world. They have been reinterpreted for each new generation, as teen films, musicals, science-fiction flicks, Japanese warrior tales, literary transformations and more.

Since October 2015, the Hogarth Shakespeare project has been commissioning some of today‚Äôs bestselling novelists to rewrite the Bard‚Äôs work with a contemporary twist. Why not pick one up for Shakespeare Week, which runs from 12 - 18 March?

The Gap of Time: The Winter‚Äôs Tale retold, by Jeanette Winterson

Jeanette Winterson transports Shakespeare to contemporary London and Leontes (Leo) becomes a hedge fund manager.

‚ÄúJeanette Winterson‚Äôs version of Shakespeare‚Äôs The Winter‚Äôs Tale vibrates with echoes of the original but tells a contemporary story of betrayal, paranoia, redemption and hope. Time itself is a player in this game of high stakes that will either end in tragedy or forgiveness, showing us that, however far we have been separated, whatever is lost shall be found.‚Äù

Shylock is my Name, by Howard Jacobson

‚Äú‚ÄòWho is this guy, Dad? What is he doing here?‚Äô

‚ÄúWith an absent wife and a daughter going off the rails, wealthy art collector and philanthropist Simon Strulovitch is in need of someone to talk to. So when he meets Shylock at a cemetery in Cheshire‚Äôs Golden Triangle, he invites him back to his house. It‚Äôs the beginning of a remarkable friendship.

‚ÄúElsewhere in the Golden Triangle, the rich, manipulative Plurabelle is the face of her own TV series, existing in a bubble of plastic surgery and lavish parties. She shares prejudices and a barbed sense of humour with her loyal friend D‚ÄôAnton, whose attempts to play Cupid involve Strulovitch‚Äôs daughter - and put a pound of flesh on the line.‚Äù

Thought provoking, challenging and entertaining. It helps if you have some familiarity with The Merchant of Venice, but this can be read as a standalone.

Vinegar Girl: The Taming of the Shrew retold, by Anne Tyler

Anne Tyler deals with the conundrum of updating the tale of a spinster who doesn‚Äôt want to marry for the 21st century by trying to push her into a Green Card marriage.

‚ÄúKate Battista is feeling stuck. How did she end up running house and home for her eccentric scientist father and uppity, pretty younger sister Bunny? Plus, she‚Äôs always in trouble at work - her pre-school charges adore her, but the adults don‚Äôt always appreciate her unusual opinions and forthright manner.

‚ÄúDr Battista has other problems. After years out in the academic wilderness, he is on the verge of a breakthrough. His research could help millions. There‚Äôs only one problem: his brilliant young lab assistant, Pyotr, is about to be deported. When Dr Battista cooks up an outrageous plan that will enable Pyotr to stay in the country, he‚Äôs relying - as usual - on Kate to help him.‚Äù

Hag-seed: The Tempest retold, by Margaret Atwood

‚ÄúFelix is at the top of his game as Artistic Director of the Makeshiweg Theatre Festival. His productions have amazed and confounded. Now he‚Äôs staging a Tempest like no other: not only will it boost his reputation, it will heal emotional wounds. Or that was the plan.

‚ÄúInstead, after an act of unforeseen treachery, Felix is living in exile in a backwoods hovel, haunted by memories of his beloved lost daughter, Miranda. And also brewing revenge.

‚ÄúAfter 12 years, revenge finally arrives in the shape of a theatre course at a nearby prison. Here, Felix and his inmate actors will put on his Tempest and snare the traitors who destroyed him. It‚Äôs magic! But will it remake Felix as his enemies fall?‚Äù

This is a beautifully judged novel, so much so that it feels like a book in Margaret Atwood‚Äôs back catalogue. It is respectful to the source but there is mischief there as well as plenty of nods to contemporary culture for the more savvy reader.

Dunbar, by Edward St Aubyn

‚ÄúHenry Dunbar, the once all-powerful head of a global corporation, is not having a good day. In his dotage he handed over care of the family firm to his two eldest daughters, Abby and Megan. But relations quickly soured, leaving him doubting the wisdom of past decisions.

‚ÄúNow imprisoned in a care home in the Lake District with only a demented alcoholic comedian as company, Dunbar starts planning his escape. As he flees into the hills, his family is hot on his heels. But who will find him first, his beloved youngest daughter, Florence, or the tigresses Abby and Megan, so keen to divest him of his estate?‚Äù

This one is fascinating. Anyone with any knowledge of Edward St Aubyn‚Äôs life and work will know that he writes about tyrannical fathers and dysfunctional families. This is a good fit for his style and certainly one of the best of the bunch.

Macbeth, by Jo Nesbo

This isn‚Äôt arriving until the beginning of April, but we know that Nesbo is going to write it as a gritty thriller. It will be interesting to see how Harry Hole‚Äôs fans take to it.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs the best cop they‚Äôve got. When a drug bust turns into a bloodbath it‚Äôs up to Inspector Macbeth and his team to clean up the mess. He‚Äôs also an ex-drug addict with a troubled past.

‚ÄúHe‚Äôs rewarded for his success. Power. Money. Respect. They‚Äôre all within reach. But a man like him won‚Äôt get to the top. Plagued by hallucinations and paranoia, Macbeth starts to unravel. He‚Äôs convinced he won‚Äôt get what is rightfully his. Unless he kills for it.‚Äù

There‚Äôs also Gillian Flynn‚Äôs version of Hamlet to look forward to in 2021!

Brandon King

I work in the Suffolk Libraries Stock Team
